com.mousebird.maply

Class RenderController

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.mousebird.maply.RenderController
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    RenderControllerInterface

    public class RenderController
extends java.lang.Object
implements RenderControllerInterface
    The Render Controller handles the object manipulation and rendering interface. It can be a standalone object, doing offline rendering or it can be attached to a BaseController and used to manage that controller's rendering.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  RenderController.ImageFormat
      Enumerated values for image types.
      static interface  RenderController.TaskManager
      We don't want to deal with threads and such down here, so the controller one level up gives us an addTask method to hand over the runnables.

      • addLight

        public void addLight(Light light)
        Add the given light to the list of active lights.
        This method will add the given light to our active lights. Most shaders will recognize these lights and do the calculations. If you have a custom shader in place, it may or may not use these. Triangle shaders use the lights, but line shaders do not.
        Specified by:
        addLight in interface RenderControllerInterface
        Parameters:
        light - Light to add.

      • removeLight

        public void removeLight(Light light)
        Remove the given light (assuming it's active) from the list of lights.
        Specified by:
        removeLight in interface RenderControllerInterface
        Parameters:
        light - Light to remove.

      • clearLights

        public void clearLights()
        Clear all the currently active lights.
        There are a default set of lights, so you'll want to do this before adding your own.
        Specified by:
        clearLights in interface RenderControllerInterface

      • resetLights

        public void resetLights()
        Reset the lighting back to its default state at startup.
        This clears out all the lights and adds in the default starting light source.
        Specified by:
        resetLights in interface RenderControllerInterface

      • addScreenMarkers

        public ComponentObject addScreenMarkers(java.util.List<ScreenMarker> markers,
                                        MarkerInfo markerInfo,
                                        RenderControllerInterface.ThreadMode mode)
        Add screen markers to the visual display. Screen markers are 2D markers that sit on top of the screen display, rather than interacting with the geometry. Their visual look is defined by the MarkerInfo class.
        Specified by:
        addScreenMarkers in interface RenderControllerInterface
        Parameters:
        markers - The markers to add to the display
        markerInfo - How the markers should look.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.
        Returns:
        This represents the screen markers for later modification or deletion.

      • addScreenMovingMarkers

        public ComponentObject addScreenMovingMarkers(java.util.List<ScreenMovingMarker> markers,
                                              MarkerInfo markerInfo,
                                              RenderControllerInterface.ThreadMode mode)
        Add moving screen markers to the visual display. These are the same as the regular screen markers, but they have a start and end point and a duration.
        Specified by:
        addScreenMovingMarkers in interface RenderControllerInterface

      • addScreenLabels

        public ComponentObject addScreenLabels(java.util.List<ScreenLabel> labels,
                                       LabelInfo labelInfo,
                                       RenderControllerInterface.ThreadMode mode)
        Add screen labels to the display. Screen labels are 2D labels that float above the 3D geometry and stay fixed in size no matter how the user zoom in or out. Their visual appearance is controlled by the LabelInfo class.
        Specified by:
        addScreenLabels in interface RenderControllerInterface
        Parameters:
        labels - Labels to add to the display.

      • addVectors

        public ComponentObject addVectors(java.util.List<VectorObject> vecs,
                                  VectorInfo vecInfo,
                                  RenderControllerInterface.ThreadMode mode)
        Add vectors to the MaplyController to display. Vectors are linear or areal features with line width, filled style, color and so forth defined by the VectorInfo class.
        Specified by:
        addVectors in interface RenderControllerInterface
        Parameters:
        vecs - A list of VectorObject's created by the user or read in from various sources.
        vecInfo - A description of how the vectors should look.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.
        Returns:
        The ComponentObject representing the vectors. This is necessary for modifying or deleting the vectors once created.

      • addLoftedPolys

        public ComponentObject addLoftedPolys(java.util.List<VectorObject> vecs,
                                      LoftedPolyInfo loftInfo,
                                      RenderControllerInterface.ThreadMode mode)
        Add Lofted Polygons to the MaplyController to display.
        Lofted polygons require areal features as outlines. The result will be a tent-like visual with optional sides and a top.
        Specified by:
        addLoftedPolys in interface RenderControllerInterface
        Parameters:
        vecs - A list of VectorObject's created by the user or read in from various sources.
        loftInfo - A description of how the lofted polygons should look.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.
        Returns:
        The ComponentObject representing the vectors. This is necessary for modifying or deleting the features once created.

      • instanceVectors

        public ComponentObject instanceVectors(ComponentObject vecObj,
                                       VectorInfo vecInfo,
                                       RenderControllerInterface.ThreadMode mode)
        Instance an existing set of vectors and modify various parameters for reuse. This is useful if you want to overlay the same vectors twice with different widths, for example.
        Specified by:
        instanceVectors in interface RenderControllerInterface

      • addWideVectors

        public ComponentObject addWideVectors(java.util.List<VectorObject> vecs,
                                      WideVectorInfo wideVecInfo,
                                      RenderControllerInterface.ThreadMode mode)
        Add wide vectors to the MaplyController to display. Vectors are linear or areal features with line width, filled style, color and so forth defined by the WideVectorInfo class.
        Wide vectors differ from regular lines in that they're implemented with a more complicated shader. They can be arbitrarily large, have textures, and have a transparent falloff at the edges. This makes them look anti-aliased.
        Specified by:
        addWideVectors in interface RenderControllerInterface
        Parameters:
        vecs - A list of VectorObject's created by the user or read in from various sources.
        wideVecInfo - A description of how the vectors should look.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.
        Returns:
        The ComponentObject representing the vectors. This is necessary for modifying or deleting the vectors once created.

      • instanceWideVectors

        public ComponentObject instanceWideVectors(ComponentObject inCompObj,
                                           WideVectorInfo wideVecInfo,
                                           RenderControllerInterface.ThreadMode mode)
        Instance an existing set of wide vectors but change their parameters.
        Wide vectors can take up a lot of memory. So if you want to display the same set with different parameters (e.g. width, color) this is the way to do it.
        Specified by:
        instanceWideVectors in interface RenderControllerInterface
        Parameters:
        inCompObj - The Component Object returned by an addWideVectors call.
        wideVecInfo - How we want the vectors to look.
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.
        Returns:
        The ComponentObject representing the instanced wide vectors. This is necessary for modifying or deleting the instance once created.

      • addShapes

        public ComponentObject addShapes(java.util.List<Shape> shapes,
                                 ShapeInfo shapeInfo,
                                 RenderControllerInterface.ThreadMode mode)
        This method will add the given MaplyShape derived objects to the current scene. It will use the parameters in the description dictionary and it will do it on the thread specified.
        Specified by:
        addShapes in interface RenderControllerInterface
        Parameters:
        shapes - An array of Shape derived objects
        shapeInfo - Info controlling how the shapes look
        mode - Where to execute the add. Choose ThreadAny by default.

      • addRenderTarget

        public void addRenderTarget(RenderTarget renderTarget)
        Add a render target to the system
        Sets up a render target and will start rendering to it on the next frame. Keep the render target around so you can remove it later.
        Specified by:
